lines.content: - Cursor free Auto model: used for most standard tasks (minor refactors, routine docs, small test scaffolds).

- GPT-5 model: used for optimizing design and nuanced testing (e.g. edge-case identification in `Storage.java`, invariants and parsing in `Parser.java`, minimal-diff refactors for `ListCommand`/`Ui`).

- Anchor prompts to exact files/classes/tests and request minimal diffs with acceptance criteria (e.g., “In `Parser.parse`, allow `yyyy/MM/dd` in the `deadline` branch only; update `ParserDeadlineTest`; don’t touch other commands”).

- Ground the assistant with precise targets: mention `Storage.save`, `Storage` serialization format (pipe-delimited T/D/E), `TaskList.asList`, and `Ui.showWelcome` when relevant so changes land in the right place on the first try.
- Pair every change with tests: ask to add/adjust `src/test/java/dukii/*Test.java` first, then implement; run `gradlew test` and require green tests before accepting edits.
- Preserve invariants and interfaces: keep storage schema stable, keep `TaskList` API unchanged, maintain existing error-message tone in `DukiiException`/`Parser` and greeting in `Ui`.
- Constrain scope and failure modes explicitly: state files not to edit, forbid unrelated refactors, and say “reject if it changes `build.gradle` or public method signatures.”
- Prefer mechanical work for AI: Javadoc, small unit tests, trivial refactors (e.g., extracting duplicate message strings), and formatting; avoid speculative redesigns.
- Decompose multi-step tasks into ordered steps: parse → tests → persist → UI message; have the assistant complete steps sequentially and verify after each.
- Ask for reasoning, demand concise output: “think through edge cases (empty desc, bad dates, off-by-one indices), then output only the final diff touching the minimal lines.”
- Set version-control discipline: stage only changed files, no commits until review; draft commit messages that are short and direct (e.g., “Support slash dates in deadline parser”).
- Safety guardrails: no new dependencies, jar stays `dukii`, no I/O outside `data/dukii.txt`, defaults remain `yyyy-MM-dd` unless tests expand coverage.
- Be explicit about acceptance criteria: name the tests expected to pass (e.g., `ParserDeadlineTest`, `ParserEventTest`, `ListCommandTest`) and the exact behavior change.
* Dukii is a personal task management application that allows users to manage
* their tasks including todos, deadlines, and events. It provides a command-line
* interface for task operations and persistent storage of tasks.

*

The application supports the following task types:

*
  • Deadline: Tasks with a specific due date

*
  • Event: Tasks with start and end dates

*

Tasks can be marked as done/pending, listed, and deleted. The application
* automatically saves tasks to persistent storage and loads them on startup.
private static final ArrayList<Task> TASKS = new ArrayList<>();
private static final TaskList TASK_LIST = new TaskList(TASKS);
private static final Storage STORAGE = new Storage(STORAGE_FILE_PATH);
private static final Ui UI = new Ui();
* The main entry point of the Dukii application.

*

This method initializes the application, loads existing tasks from storage,
* and starts the main command loop. It handles user input, parses commands,
* executes them, and manages the application lifecycle.
UI.showMessage("Oh no my sweety, I couldn't load your tasks. Starting fresh.");
UI.showMessage("Oh no my sweety, something unexpected happened. Please try again.");
* Safely saves the current task list to persistent storage.

*

This method handles the saving operation and provides user feedback
* if the save operation fails. It catches IOException and displays an
* appropriate error message to the user.
UI.showMessage("Oh no my sweety, I couldn't save your tasks. Please try again.");
* Command implementation for exiting the Dukii application.

*

The bye command gracefully terminates the application after displaying
* a farewell message to the user. This command overrides the default behavior
* of other commands by indicating that it should exit the application and
* that it doesn't modify the task storage.

*

The command format is simply "bye" with no additional parameters.
* Executes the bye command by displaying a farewell message.

*

This method shows a goodbye message to the user. The actual
* application termination is handled by the main loop when it detects
* that this command's isExit() method returns true.
* @param tasks the task list (not used in this command)
* @param ui the user interface for displaying the farewell message
* @param storage the storage system (not used in this command)
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Indicates that this command should terminate the application.

*

When the main loop detects that this method returns true, it will
* break out of the input loop and close the application.
* @return true to indicate that the application should exit
* Indicates that this command does not modify the task storage.

*

Since exiting the application doesn't change any task data,
* this method returns false to prevent unnecessary save operations.
* @return false since this command doesn't modify storage
* Abstract base class for all command implementations in the Dukii application.

*

This class defines the contract that all command implementations must follow.
* Commands are responsible for executing specific operations on tasks, updating
* the user interface, and potentially modifying persistent storage.

*

Each command implementation should override the {@code execute} method to
* provide specific functionality. The default implementations of {@code isExit}
* and {@code modifiesStorage} can be overridden as needed.
* Executes the command with the given task list, user interface, and storage.

*

This method should be implemented by all concrete command classes to
* perform their specific operations. The method may throw DukiiException
* if the command execution fails due to invalid input or other errors.
* @param tasks the task list to operate on
* @param ui the user interface for displaying messages
* @param storage the storage system for persisting changes
* @throws DukiiException if the command execution fails
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws DukiiException;
* Indicates whether this command should terminate the application.

*

By default, commands do not terminate the application. Override this
* method in commands that should cause the application to exit (e.g., bye command).
* @return true if the command should exit the application, false otherwise
* Indicates whether this command modifies the task storage.

*

By default, commands are assumed to modify storage. Override this method
* in commands that don't modify storage (e.g., list command) to prevent
* @return true if the command modifies storage, false otherwise
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws DukiiException;

* Constructs a new DeadlineCommand with the specified description and due date.

ui.showMessage("Got it. I've added this task:");
ui.showMessage("Now you have " + tasks.getSize() + " task(s) in the list.");
* Command implementation for removing a task from the task list.

*

The delete command allows users to permanently remove a specific task
* from their task list. Once deleted, a task cannot be recovered. The task

*

The command format is: "delete <index>" where index is the number
* of the task as shown in the list command output.

This method validates the task index, removes the corresponding task,

The deletion is permanent and cannot be undone.

ui.showMessage("Now you have " + tasks.getSize() + " task(s) in the list.");

* Command implementation for displaying all tasks in the task list.

*

The list command shows all currently stored tasks with their completion
* status and descriptions. Tasks are numbered sequentially starting from 1
* for easy reference in other commands like mark, unmark, and delete.

*

The command format is simply "list" with no additional parameters.

This method checks if the task list is empty and provides appropriate

ui.showMessage("Here are the tasks in your list:");

ui.showMessage("This task is already marked as done~");

* Storage class responsible for persisting and loading task data to/from the file system.

*

This class handles the serialization and deserialization of tasks to ensure
* data persistence across application sessions. It supports three task types:
* todos, deadlines, and events, each with their own serialization format.

*

The storage format uses pipe-separated values with the following structure:

*

Status is represented as "0" for pending and "1" for completed tasks.

* and returns an empty task list. If the parent directory doesn't exist,
* it creates the necessary directory structure.

* Abstract base class representing a task in the Dukii application.

*

A task is a unit of work that can be tracked and managed. Each task has
* a description and a completion status. Tasks can be marked as done or pending,
* and they provide a string representation for display purposes.

*

This class serves as the foundation for different types of tasks such as
* todos, deadlines, and events. Concrete implementations should override the
* {@code getTaskType} method to provide their specific type identifier.
* Constructs a new task with the given description.

*

The task is initially marked as not done (pending).
* @param description the description of the task

*

This method changes the completion status of the task to done.

*

This method changes the completion status of the task to pending.
* Checks if this task is completed.

* Gets the type identifier for this task.

This method should be implemented by concrete task classes to return
* a unique identifier representing the task type (e.g., "T" for todo,
* @return a string representing the task type
* Returns a string representation of this task.

*

The format is: [Type][Status] Description, where Type is the task type,
* Status is "X" for done or " " for pending, and Description is the task description.
* @return a formatted string representation of the task
* A container class that manages a collection of tasks.

*

TaskList provides a wrapper around an ArrayList of tasks, offering

*

This class is designed to be simple and focused, primarily providing
* access to the underlying task collection. Future enhancements could include
* additional task management methods such as filtering, sorting, or searching.
